entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
This third post in my series gives an overview of the very latest user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, which are so new that they are only released for customers to try them out via beta testing. They are all AI-related, for My Home, for working with SAP Fiori elements based applications, as well as for some individual application use cases.

In case you missed them, Part 2 covers the generally available UX innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, and Part 1 explains how users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule, as well as providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services.

This post covers these innovations for:

My Home

  • AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications.

SAP Fiori elements based applications

  • AI-assisted easy fill.
  • AI-assisted error explanation.

Individual application uses cases

  • AI-assisted payment exception analysis.
  • Accounting accruals agent.

If you want to try out these features as beta testers, then sign-up for beta testing here:

  • Q3/25: Latest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

Find out more about beta programs and how to Get Involved Early with SAP innovations in general.

 

My Home UX Innovations

AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home

With this feature, you can now get details of a Business Situation shown directly in place on My Home, and even initiate quick actions or make changes to business data there. This is achieved by expanding the Situation card on My Home when you click on it, as you can see in Figure 1, or in action in this video:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:00 min.)

Figure 1: Beta: AI-Assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home. Alt Text: An image with two screenshots: the upper one shows the top part of My Home showing three Situation cards in the To-Dos section. One titled ‚ÄúThis sales quotation is about to expire‚Äù is highlighted and linked with an arrow to an expanded card shown in the second screenshot ‚Äì the card is taller and wider, contains a summary on the left with three action buttons ‚ÄúChange Validity‚Äù, ‚ÄúReject All Items‚Äù, ‚ÄúClose Situation‚Äù, and more details on the right.

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications

So far, as I outlined in Part 2, you can use natural language and AI to personalize your My Home by adding Insights Cards. Now, with this beta functionality, you can use natural language to find and add applications and insights tiles.

If you have the functionality activated in your system, you‚Äôll see the AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù in the salutation bar at the top of My Home, as shown at the top of Figure 2. Clicking on this brings a pop-over with the option to add Insights Cards or, as shown, Apps & Insights Tiles. By describing what you want to do, the system will propose suitable applications and Insights Tiles. If you select them and click ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù, they will be added, either as an entry in your Apps Favorites section, or in the Insights Tiles section. Figure 2 shows these main steps.

Figure 2: Beta: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications. Alt Text: The image shows three screenshots: at the top an extract of My Home showing the blue salutation bar, with an AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù on the right. An arrow has been added linking it to the second screenshot, where a popover ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù is shown, where the user has entered ‚ÄúI want to monitor sales orders what app should I use to do this‚Äù, and two of four results are listed and visualized: ‚ÄúTrack Sales Orders‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Sales Orders‚Äù (shown as an insight tile). Below that a screenshot of the outcome in My Home: the former is added to Apps Favorites, the latter to Insights Tiles.

 Watch a demo:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:11 min.)

 For a summary of all the news for My Home, both generally available and for beta-testing, read this blog post:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?

 

AI UX Innovations for Applications based on SAP Fiori elements

AI-Assisted Easy Fill

Users often receive requests via e-mails or chats to change data in the system. This new feature makes it much easier to update the fields in the various sections of an object page based on SAP Fiori elements, such as a sales order. Instead of manually scanning the e-mail and navigating to the relevant sections and fields in the object page, you can just paste the text into Easy Fill and it will automatically identify the correct fields to update, with proposals for the correct entries.

The power of AI means that the new values do not have to be exactly contained in the text. Figure 3 shows an example, where the new address is given without actually mentioning the name of the city, only the street and post code, along with an abbreviation for the state and country (‚ÄúBW DE‚Äù). As you can see, the proposed new values are correct, despite this missing or abbreviated information.

Figure 3: Beta: AI-Assisted Easy Fill for SAP Fiori elements based applications. Alt-Text: A screenshot showing an Easy Fill pop-over, with a text entry field on the left with text from a customer e-mail informing about a change of name and address for their store, and on the left showing the ‚ÄúFilled Fields‚Äù, a list of seven fields for which new values are proposed.

Watch a demo:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Easy Fill of SAP Fiori Elements-Based Applications in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (1:15 min.)

Note that this feature is only available for applications based on SAP Fiori elements.

AI-Assisted Error Explanation

We started beta testing for this with the 2502 release, and have decided to continue with beta testing in this 2508 release. The explanation I gave in my February blog post continues to apply:

New users who are unfamiliar with the system may find that the short error messages give too little information for them to fully understand the issue, and what to do about it. The AI-Assisted Error Explanation (beta) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition summarizes information which explains the error and provide a recommendation for how to resolve it. Figure 8 shows an example where a user has entered a Sold-to-Party ID which does not exist in the system.

Note that this feature is also only available for applications based on SAP Fiori elements.

Figure 4: Beta: AI-Assisted Error Explanation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502. ALT Text: On the left part of a data entry screen is shown, with the field ‚ÄúSold-to Party containing ‚ÄúABC‚Äù marked red and below that a  popover with an error message ‚ÄúNo customer master record exists for sold-to-party ABC‚Äù, and in the text line below that the AI icon followed by ‚ÄúGenerate Explanation‚Äù. A fat arrow leads from this text to the image on the right, which indicates what happens when you click on this text: you get a popover with an short Explanation section and a longer Resolution section with numbered actions.

If you want a summary of the latest such generic AI-assisted features, both generally available and for beta-testing, with some different examples, have a look at this blog post:

  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

AI Innovations in Individual Application Use Cases

AI-Assisted Payment Exception Analysis

Most payments of invoices from vendors are automated, but sometimes data is missing or incorrect so that an automatic payment fails. These issues are collected in error logs, and one of the more tedious tasks of Accounts Payable Accountant is to scan through these error logs, understand what went wrong and why, and then fix it.

With AI-assisted payment exception analysis, we make this task much easier and less tedious: users can choose an entry in the error log and simply click on the AI button ‚ÄúAnalyze Exception‚Äù. The system then provide an analysis, a recommended resolution in natural language, as well as a links to a selection of the most relevant log entries. If a user wants all the relevant logs, they are just one click away. Figure 5 shows what this looks like:

Figure 5: Beta: AI-assisted payment exception analysis. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Revise Payment Proposals applicatin, showing a list of payment exceptions grouped by Error ID. Four error IDs are listed, covering 419 exceptions. One is expanded and has one exception listed in the row below. The main part of the image is a pop-over ‚ÄúException Analysis and Resolution‚Äù, with natural language explanations in sections ‚ÄúAnalysis‚Äù and ‚ÄúResolution‚Äù and a section ‚ÄúLogs‚Äù with a list of selected logs, and a button to select ‚ÄúAll Logs‚Äù.

Alternatively, watch this:

  • Video: AI-assisted payment exception analysis (1:20 min.)

Accounting Accruals Agent

An accrual is an accounting entry which represents revenue which has been earned or expenses which have incurred but for which no payment has yet been made. That way, when looking at a particular period such as a quarter or a month, accountants get a more accurate picture of a company‚Äôs financial position. For example, if a service was delivered, but not paid for within the period, having the accrual means that the cost of delivering the service and the revenue associated with it both appear in the summary for the period.

Calculating accruals and deferrals is often time very time consuming. It can also require estimates based on historical data, if for example invoices have not yet been created, or payment amounts can be reduced if payments are made quickly in the future.

The new accounting accruals agent can significantly speed this up, potentially reducing the time spent on these activities by 80%! This frees up accountants to work on more value-adding activities, such as analysis. As you can see in Figure 6, the agent creates a list of accrual proposals. For each proposal, you can details on the recommendation, including an explanation for the basis of the recommendation.

Figure 6: Beta: Accrual Proposals made by the accounting accruals agent. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Accrual Proposals applications, showing a list of six accrual proposals on the left. The details of the one selected are shown on the right, showing the recommended accrual amount, the proposed line items and a section ‚ÄúBasis of AI Recommendation‚Äù with a natural language explanation along with a bar chart and a forecast line for the trend per month.

Watch this video to find out more:

  • Video: Accounting Accruals Agent (1:36 min.)

 

Continue Reading - UX Innovations in SAP SuccessFactors

I hope you enjoyed this third part, covering the new UX innovations available for beta testing with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508. Here is the link to part four, covering exciting new UX innovations available in the SAP Success Factors 1H2025 release:

entry.title: New in SAP Mobile Start V2.4: Integrate and Launch SAP Document AI on Mobile
entry.content:
With the SAP Mobile Start‚ÄØ2.4 release, users can leverage SAP Document‚ÄØAI‚Äîintegrated seamlessly within the Mobile Start app‚Äîto transform document handling into a secure, intelligent, and automated experience. They can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. This streamlines processing, cuts down manual work, and boosts data accuracy throughout your operations. In this blog, I'll walk you through the integration steps, prerequisites, and configuration details needed to bring SAP Document AI capabilities to your mobile users. 

Preconditions 

Before you begin, ensure the following prerequisites are fulfilled. 

Subscribe to SAP Document AI

Ensure that your SAP BTP subaccount is subscribed to the Document Information Extraction service (document-information-extraction-application-ias with embedded_edition instance). Once complete, access the SAP Document AI workspace from your BTP subscriptions to configure document types and schemas relevant to your business scenarios. For more information, refer to the official user guide. 

Enable Identity Authentication for SAP Build Work Zone

In SAP Build Work Zone, navigate to Site Manager > Settings, and ensure Identity Authentication is enabled. 

Screenshot: Enabling Identity Authentication in SAP Build Work Zone Settings

Note: Valid only for SAP Build Work Zone subscription made before 20 March 2025.

Configure Trust Relationship for API Access

To allow SAP Build Work Zone to consume SAP Document AI APIs, you need to add a dependency in the SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) administration console: 

  • Go to the Applications tab 
  • Select the SAP Build Work Zone application 
  • Under Dependencies, add a new entry with: 
  • Name: documentai (or any unique name) 
  • Application: Select the ‚ÄúSAP Document AI‚Äù entry in your IAS tenant 

Create Destination for SAP Mobile Start

To authorize SAP Mobile Start App to access SAP Document AI, create a destination in your BTP subaccount with the following settings: 

  • Name: sapdocumentaimobilestartintegration 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Authentication: NoAuthentication 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • URL: (Use https://<your-tenant-url-endpoint>/document-ai/v1, located in Document AI instance > service key > endpoints > backend > URL) 

Add the following additional properties: 

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination = true
  • HTML5.IASDependencyName = documentai (dependency name created in SAP Cloud Identity Services) 

Once completed, both‚ÄØSAP Build Work Zone‚ÄØand‚ÄØSAP Mobile Start‚ÄØare authorized to access SAP Document AI. You can control user access in SAP Document AI using default authorization policies via Identity Authentication service. (Learn more)

Configuring tile for SAP Document AI access in mobile 

To make SAP Document AI accessible via SAP Mobile Start: 

Step 1: Create a New App in Site Manager  

In SAP Build Work Zone, navigate to Site Manager > Content Manager and create a new App. 

  • URL: https://<your-tenant-url>/launchpad?sap-ushell-config=headerless#InboundDocument-manageInDocumentAI
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è Use sap-ushell-config=headerless to hide the launchpad header
Step 2: Configure Navigation Parameters 

In the Navigation tab, add the following parameters: 

  • name: Schema name - Optional (from SAP Document AI workspace > Schemas tab) 
  • latest: true, this signifies that only the latest version of the schema is used 
  • client_ID: Client ID (from SAP Document AI workspace > Settings), preset to ‚Äòdefault‚Äô 
  • instance_ID: Instance ID (from SAP Document AI workspace > Settings or BTP account > Instances > Select SAP Document AI instance) 
  • showWorkspaceHeader: true 
Step 3: Configure Visualization 

You can set your own preferred title, subtitle, icon. 

  • Visualisation Type: Static Tile 
  • Add the following name-value parameters:  
  • mobilestart.type: documentAi 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.clientId: (as specified in Navigation Tab parameters) 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.instanceId: (as specified in Navigation Tab parameters) 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.documentSchemaId: Optional - needed if only a specific schema scenario should be enabled, otherwise all active schemas will be shown to the end user. You can find Schema ID in SAP Document AI workspace > Schemas tab 

Screenshot: SAP Document AI Tile Visualization in SAP Build Work Zone

You‚Äôve now created a fully functional SAP Document AI tile for SAP Mobile Start! üöÄ 

User Experience in SAP Mobile Start 

As a business user, you can locate the newly created SAP Document AI tile in the SAP Mobile Start app using the Search function. For easier access, you can also add the tile to your Favorites. When you tap the tile, you‚Äôll be directed to a native document selection screen. Depending on how the service was configured by the administrator, you may have the option to select a document type and schema. If the tile is configured for a specific schema use case, it will be automatically selected. 

Screenshot: SAP Document AI tile in SAP Mobile Start App 

Upload Options 

  1. Scan via Camera ‚Äì Leverages the device‚Äôs native camera with real-time preview, cropping, rotation, and filtering. Multiple scans are compiled into a single PDF. 
  2. Select Images from Gallery ‚Äì Users choose previously captured images which are compiled into a single PDF. 
  3. Select File from File Explorer ‚Äì Users upload a single PDF from their device‚Äôs file system. 

 Screenshot: Scanning a document via device‚Äôs native camera  

Upload Validation & Handling 

Before uploading a document, the app performs several validation checks to ensure compatibility. The file size must not exceed 50 MB, and the document should contain no more than 100 pages. Additionally, file names are automatically sanitized to remove any invalid characters. Once these checks are successfully passed, the upload process begins, with a visible progress bar indicating status. Android users can upload multiple documents synchronously.  

After the upload is complete, the document extraction workflow is triggered, and users receive a success notification confirming the process. 

Track Status and Review Document 

To monitor the progress of document extraction, simply open the Document Overview from the overflow menu within the document selection screen. This action launches the mobile-optimized SAP Document AI UI, providing a clear and intuitive view of the status, allowing reviews and other updates related to your uploaded documents. 

Screenshot: Track status and review document via mobile optimized UI 

Conclusion 

With the release of SAP Mobile Start 2.4 and the seamless integration of SAP Document AI, business users now benefit from a truly mobile-first, intelligent document processing experience. Whether it's capturing receipts on the go, processing invoices, or extracting data from complex forms, SAP Document AI empowers users to automate workflows efficiently‚Äîright from their mobile devices. This integration brings the power of AI-driven document handling directly to your fingertips, enabling smarter, faster, and more scalable business operations.

entry.title: Simple RAP based Managed UI development with Create & Delete actions on custom BillDoc header table
entry.content:
Introduction

In this project, you set out to build a Simple Managed RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming) application on SAP BTP ABAP Environment using Eclipse ADT. The goal is to design a lightweight Billing Document Header maintenance app with Create and Delete capabilities, following best practices for Managed RAP development.

The application uses a custom transparent table for storing billing document header data and implements standard RAP layers ‚Äî Database Table, Interface View, Projection View, Metadata Annotations, Behavior Definitions, Service Definition, and Service Binding.

By leveraging Managed RAP,  you do not need to write custom CRUD logic ‚Äî the framework auto-generates this functionality, allowing you to focus purely on data modelling, UI annotations, and service exposure. This demonstrates how RAP accelerates application development in the cloud while complying with ABAP Cloud clean-core principles.

 

Objectives:

Creating a Simple Managed RAP based UI using BTP and Eclipse IDE with Create & Delete actions on custom Billing Document header table.

Requirements/Task(s):

  1. Create required Database Table(s)
  2. Create CDS views for the Database Table ‚Äì
    • Interface View and
    • Consumption (Projection) View
  3. Create Metadata View on Consumption View
  4. Create Behavior Definition for Interface View
  5. Create Behavior Definition for Consumption View
  6. Create Service Definition for Consumption View
  7. Service Binding for the Service Definition
  8. Test the Application

Objects List

 

Outline the steps/plan for your project:

  1. Step1: Create Database Table (Eclipse - Data Dictionary-Database Table)

 

 

Check the created Database Table structure (Right click ‚Äì Open With - Data Preview)

 

Step 2: Create Interface Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

           

 

Step 3: Create Consumption/Projection Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

           

Step 4: Create Metadata that helps with designing aspects of the UI (Right click on the Projection View you created and select new "Metadata Definition")

           

Step 5: Create Behaviour Definition - one fore Interface view and one for Consumption view you have created

Step 5a: Create Behaviour Definition for the interface view ((Right click the Interface CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

                       

Step 5b: Create Behaviour Definition for the Projection view (Right click the Projection CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

Step 6: Create Service definition (Right click CDS Projection View and click "New Service Definition")

Expose the Consumption View CDS.

                       

 

Step 7: Create Service Binding (Right click on the new Service definition you created and choose "New Service Binding" and Choose OData V4 version for the UI)

Select the Service Definition displayed on the versions section of the page and hit "Publish" button.

It will take some time. Once it is done, a Service URL will be created and the binding will be displayed.

  

 

Step 8:  Test the Application: Select the Entity and hit Preview button, a new Window will be opened with the RAP UI App you created.

                    

 

 

A new window will open with the UI for the Application we created:

 

 

Click ‚ÄúGo‚Äù Button, so that the values are pulled from the Database table to be shown on the screen.

 

 

You can see the database records displayed on the screen. The Create and Delete buttons are available for creating new records and deleting existing records. Since this is Managed RAP application, the code necessary for the Create and delete operations are handled automatically by the Framework, there is no explicit code necessary for these simple actions. If customizations are required then it can be handled via Implementation Class (Behaviour Pool Classes) of the Behaviour Definition.

Project link:

https://github.com/ABAPAnitha/RAP-for-Bill-doc-header-and-Items

Conclusion

This project highlights how quickly and efficiently a Managed RAP application can be built on SAP BTP using the ABAP RESTful Programming Model. The framework automatically handled the Create and Delete operations, proving the advantage of Managed scenarios where minimal custom coding is required.

We also learned how UI metadata annotations can be used to control the look and feel of the Fiori Elements-based UI without any frontend coding, and how RAP‚Äôs structured approach ‚Äî from database table to service binding ‚Äî enables a clean, maintainable, and extensible application design.

Going forward, you can extend this solution with:

  • Custom business logic in Behavior Pool classes,

  • Associations to billing item entities for a complete billing document structure,

  • Advanced annotations for richer UI interactions.

Overall, the Managed RAP approach proved to be a fast, cloud-compliant, and developer-friendly way to deliver maintainable SAP applications aligned with the ABAP Cloud strategy.

      const oCityModel = new JSONModel();

      const sKey = oEvent.getParameter("selectedItem").getKey();
      const [lat, lon] = sKey.split(",");
      this.loadCurrentWeather(lat, lon);
    },

    loadCurrentWeather: async function (lat, lon) {
      const apiKey = "e21c9996e2801f22e2bd0f7d11d1b367";
      const url = `https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?lat=${lat}&lon=${lon}&appid=${apiKey}&lang=tr`;

      try {
        const response = await fetch(url);
        const data = await response.json();

        const row = {
          dt_txt: new Date(data.dt * 1000).toLocaleString("tr-TR"),
          temp: data.main.temp,
          feels_like: data.main.feels_like,
          humidity: data.main.humidity,
          wind_speed: data.wind.speed,
          weather_desc: data.weather?.[0]?.description || ""
        };

        const oWeatherModel = new JSONModel({ Forecast: [row] });
        this.getView().setModel(oWeatherModel, "weatherModel");
      } catch (err) {
        console.error("Anlƒ±k hava durumu alƒ±namadƒ±:", err);
      }
    }
  });
});

entry.title: How Key Users Create Consistent Text Changes with SAPUI5 Flexibility
entry.content:
SAPUI5 flexibility to adapt standard SAP apps

SAPUI5 is SAP‚Äôs strategic Web framework for SAP Fiori. SAPUI5 flexibility allows developers, key users and end users to adapt standard apps with simple drag-and-drop tools. It supports a clean core approach by enabling on-stack extensions without requiring any predefined extension points. Discover all the capabilities in SAPUI5 Flexibility - All You Need to Know.


Changing texts of SAP standard apps

One common use case in this context is changing labels of SAP standard apps to match the terminology used by end users. Similarly, a table column might need to show either the ID of a business object, its text, or even both.


New Feature: Consistent text changes across multiple fields

Previously, if a field appeared multiple times (e.g., in the filter bar and a table column), each occurrence had to be changed separately. Now in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and with SAPUI5 1.136 on SAP BTP, text changes are now applied at the model level in annotations. To do this, the key user does not have to make a decision, the change is automatically applied at the 'lowest possible level'.

I need to be more specific about what the mentioned text changes are, for which this logic applies:

  • Changing labels: Key users can change the field labels according to the terminology used by end users:
    Dialog to change a label
  • Changing text arrangements: By setting the text arrangement, key users can show the descriptive text of some business entity only, the text together with the technical ID or just the ID:
    Dialog to change a text arrangement

The new logic allows key users to focus on the business data model rather than the app's implementation details, enhancing efficiency when adapting standard apps. Also, business users can work more productively with the right text helping them to identify the data they need.

Note: This logic works with annotations and is available in apps based on SAP Fiori elements patterns or using building blocks of the Flexible Programming Model. For more details, see the documentation: Renaming a UI Element and Changing the Text Arrangement.


Going forward

The UI5 team plans* to extend this logic to other types of changes, beyond simple text changes. We will share more details in official UI5 channels like the SAPUI5 Road Map, the SAPUI5 What's New, and documentation in What is SAPUI5 Flexibility.

By the way, be sure to follow the latest updates in Key User Adaptation. These new features are designed to streamline your workflow and enhance productivity of your business users:

"What's New" for Key Users

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 4: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More)
entry.content:
This fourth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP SuccessFactors. It covers Joule and many AI-based UX innovations along with enhanced user experiences. By following the career of Jon, who starts by applying for a job and then grows within the company, you can see how our latest user experience innovations help business users (employees and managers), work more effectively.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Also, if you missed it, do have a look at the many UX innovations which already came out end of last year with the SAP SuccessFactors 2H2024 release:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 3: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).

The 1H2025 release comes with a large number of UX innovations across the whole portfolio. In the following sections, I‚Äôll summarize the main highlights by following the career of Jon, and showing how the new AI-powered UX innovations help:

  • Jon find the right job with the help of the new guided application experience.
  • Managers move through the hiring process more efficiently, rating skills and competencies of candidates with Joule, and getting AI-assisted interview insights.
  • Jon understand the main features available to him in his employee HR applications.
  • Jon get an easy-to-understand overview of his benefits and payroll.
  • Jon use natural language with Joule to get questions answered and detailed information about pay statements, not only from at his desk but also via mobile phone.
  • Jon learn more, with learning overview and skilled-based learning recommendations.
  • Jon and his manager to manage goals and performance reviews, with AI-insights making his manager‚Äôs job a lot easier.

One more innovation is the new alumni experience, for departing and departed employees, helping them to

  • Manage personal information and access important documents during and after the off-boarding process.

To get the complete picture of all the new SuccessFactors innovations, have a look at the links in the ‚ÄúFurther Information ‚Äú section towards the end of this post.

 

Find the Right Job With New Guided Application Experience

Jon is applying for a job at a company which uses SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, and finds the whole process very intuitive, thanks to the new guided application experience, as well as the further enhancements in the reimagined candidate experience.

Figure 1 shows the new guided application experience. This attractive UI guides applicants through the required steps, with AI-assistance provided along the way. For example, Figure 1 shows the AI button ‚ÄúSuggest Skills‚Äù, which can help candidates when listing their own skills by indicating other skills which they may also have but did not consider mentioning.

Figure 1: Guided job application experience with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot of a six-step guided activity, with the six steps running horizontally across the top of the screen: ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù, ‚ÄúProfile‚Äù, ‚ÄúSkills Information‚Äù, ‚ÄúEmployment‚Äù, ‚ÄúEducation‚Äù, ‚ÄúReview‚Äù. The screen shows ‚ÄúSkills Information‚Äù, with ten skills already selected, a search field for adding a skill and an AI ‚ÄúSuggest Skills‚Äù button.

Once Jon has gone through the guided steps, he can use the updated and refreshed applications dashboard that gives an overview of his applications with easy access to post-application steps, and to completed and in-progress applications. If Jon wants to review his candidate profile and make adjustments, this is also easier now with the refreshed candidate profile. See examples of these, and more, here:

  • Blog post: 1H 2025: Explore the Reimagined Candidate Experience and New AI-Assisted Capabilities in Recruiting.
  • Documentation: The Reimagined Candidate Experience.

 

Joule and AI-Assisted Interview Insights Help Managers Recruit

Providing Interview Feedback with Joule

Once the interview has taken place, each interviewer needs to summarize their feedback on the candidates, such as Jon. This can now be done easily using Joule and natural language, where you can say who you want to give feedback for and assing the ratings all in one go, as you can see in Figure 2.

Figure 2: Providing interview feedback with Joule. Alt Text: An image of Joule showing a chat, with the first entry by the user being ‚ÄúMike Wang‚Äù, followed by a text asking the user to provide feedback for him, explaining the scale 1 to 5 and providing a text for copying into the chat listing the five areas to rate, and a line for overall comment and one for recommendation. The user has copied the text into their response and added the ratings, comment and recommendation (‚Äúyes‚Äù). 

AI-Assisted Interview Insights

When multiple interviewers are involved, the recruiting manager needs to consolidate the feedback from all of them, based on their ratings of competencies as well as individual remarks. This is where the AI-assisted interview insights comes in handy: by clicking on the AI ‚Äúgenerate‚Äù button, the manager gets a natural language summary of the interviewer‚Äôs feedback on the candidate Jon. This is provided in sections Overview, Strengths, Concerns, Interviewer‚Äôs Overall Feedback, with a separate section Data Referenced that provides an overview of the inputs used to create the AI-assisted insights. Figure 3 shows an example, and Figure 4 shows it in action.

Not only does this help the manager save time and be more efficient, it also helps her be more effective: the feedback across multiple candidates is consolidated consistently, ensuring that all aspects of a candidate‚Äôs interview feedback are consolidated and uniformly presented. Furthermore, key insights are highlighted.

Figure 3: AI-assisted interview insights with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over with interview insights in natural langauge, in sections ‚ÄúOverview‚Äù, ‚ÄúStrengths‚Äù, ‚ÄúConcerns‚Äù, and ‚ÄúInterviewer‚Äôs Overall Feedback‚Äù. Bottom right has an AI button ‚ÄúRegenerate‚Äù and a button ‚ÄúClose‚Äù.

Figure 4: AI-assisted interview insights in action with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. Alt Text: A short video (GIF) showing a user press the AI button ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù and showing the resulting insights, similar to what is shown in Figure 3.

Find out more:

Jon got the job, and getting started is made easy for him with the onboarding checklist I featured in my February blog post. Now, when he starts using SAP SuccessFactors for the first time, to get some of his on-boarding tasks done, he gets built-in guidance via WalkMe, which explains applications step by step.

Figure 5: An example of WalkMe providing guidance for SAP SuccessFactors users: first explaining the People Profile (upper image), then explaining the Spotlight (lower image). Alt Text: The upper image shows the People Profile for a user, with contact details on the left and cards for Skills, Competencies, Mentoring, Organization, About Me Video, Upcoming Absence on the right. A pop-over hovers above the list on the left with an explanation of the purpose of the People Profile and two buttons ‚ÄúNext‚Äù and greyed-out ‚ÄúBack‚Äù.

Easy-to-Understand Overview of Benefits and Payroll

Now that Jon is more familiar with SAP SuccessFactors, and has been on the job for a while, he‚Äôd like to get an overview of the various benefits he has enrolled in, along with details of his payroll, such as his pay statement along with pay related information. This is now easy with the enhanced People Profile in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, which provides quick access to the various parts of your benefits (Figure 6) and payroll information (Figure 7). entry.title: Converting a Smart Filter into a Smart MultiComboBox in SAPUI5
entry.content:
Introduction

Sometimes a regular Smart Filter isn‚Äôt enough ,especially when the field values are case-sensitive.
By switching to a Smart MultiComboBox filter, we can let users pick multiple exact matches from a predefined list, avoiding case-related headaches and making filtering faster.

 

Prerequisites

  • A CAPM entity your Smart Table is bound to.
  • A group-by view  or entity that will return distinct values for your filter field.

 

Step 1: Understanding the current filter setup

Right now, your Smart Filter Bar probably has a multi-value token input for status.
We‚Äôre going to replace that with a MultiComboBox so users can simply tick the statuses they want, without worrying about typing the exact case.

 

Step 2: Create the dropdown source entity

Here‚Äôs an example CDS view to provide unique status values:

entity StatusDropDown as

    select from mlc.Employees {
      key status
    } group by status;
  • key status ‚Üí Marks status as the unique identifier in the list.
  • group by status ‚Üí Ensures we only get distinct statuses (case-sensitive).
  • This becomes the data source for the MultiComboBox items.

Step 3: Add XML namespaces

Make sure your XML file includes:

xmlns:smartfilterbar="sap.ui.comp.smartfilterbar"

xmlns:smartField="sap.ui.comp.smartfield"

xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"

Step 4: Replace smart filter with a Smart MultiComboBox

<smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration

    key="status"

    index="30"

    label="Status"

    visibleInAdvancedArea="true"

    filterType="searchExpression"

    groupId="_BASIC">

   

    <smartfilterbar:customControl>

        <MultiComboBox

            id="StatusDropDown"

            items="{path: '/StatusDropDown', sorter: {path: 'status'}}">

            <items>

                <core:Item key="{status}" text="{status}" />

            </items>

        </MultiComboBox>

    </smartfilterbar:customControl>

</smartfilterbar:ControlConfiguration>
  • We bind the MultiComboBox to the /StatusDropDown entity.
  • The status field is both the key and display text.
  • Sorting ensures the list looks organized.

 

Step 5: Hook into beforeRebindTable

Add this in your Smart Table XML:

beforeRebindTable="onBeforeRebindTable"

Step 6: Import libraries in your controller

"sap/ui/model/Filter",
"sap/ui/model/FilterOperator",

 

Step 7: Filtering logic for multiple selections

onBeforeRebindTable: function (oEvent) {

    const oBindingParams = oEvent.getParameter("bindingParams");

    const aStatus = this.getView().byId("StatusDropDown").getSelectedKeys();

    if (aStatus && aStatus.length > 0) {
        const orFilters = aStatus.map(status =>
            new Filter("status", FilterOperator.EQ, status)
        );

        oBindingParams.filters.push(
            new Filter({ filters: orFilters, and: false }) // OR logic
        );

    }

}

Step 8: Test it out

Reload the app, open the filter bar, and you should see your MultiComboBox instead of the regular filter.
Pick a few statuses  and the table should only show matching records.

 

Conclusion

By converting a multi-value Smart Filter into a Smart MultiComboBox, we:

  • Gave users the flexibility to select multiple exact matches without typing.
  • Avoided case-sensitivity issues by letting the system pull valid values directly from the backend.
  • Made the filtering process faster and more reliable for real-world datasets where values like Active, active, and ACTIVE might all exist.

This approach is clean, reusable, and works seamlessly with Smart Table + Smart Filter Bar setups in SAPUI5.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
This fifth post in my series gives an overview of latest UX innovations in SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass, products for managing your spend (procurement) and external workforce. For SAP Ariba: Joule is now available for selected products, on-boarding guidance is provided by WalkMe, and we have some additional AI-assistance in SAP Ariba Category Management, amongst other enhancements. For SAP Fieldglass, Joule is now available too, and the SOW (Statement of Work) dashboard can now be adapted per user role, ensuring that users see what fits best for them. Also, you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

 

SAP Ariba

Here are the recent UX innovations that I have picked:

  • On-boarding guidance via WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform.
  • Joule, our AI copilot, available for selected SAP Ariba products.
  • UX enhancements in Category Management: Supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, plus some more minor enhancements in details.
  • Integration of the SAP User Research Panel into selected products‚Äô built-in user feedback surveys.

On-boarding guidance via WalkMe

When new employees join the procurement team, we now make it easier for them to get up and running with SAP Ariba by providing enhanced step-by-step guidance on how to get typical tasks done in the system. With the 2508 release, we provide WalkMe for the following SAP Ariba products:

  • SAP Ariba Buying

  • SAP Ariba Invoice Management
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing

Supplier Preferencing

When buying from various suppliers, it‚Äôs good to know how these suppliers view their relationship with your company. Do they value your custom highly? Or at the opposite extreme, do they see you as a nuisance, i.e. low volume but high effort and hence unprofitable?

Supplier preferencing is an established approach that helps organizations understand how they are perceived by vendors. By leveraging this insight, businesses can strengthen supplier relationships, foster collaboration, and improve supply chain effectiveness.

Supplier preferencing involves evaluating how suppliers view a buying organization based on two key dimensions:

  • Attractiveness of Account: How appealing the buying organization is to the supplier, influenced by factors like reputation, growth potential, and ease of doing business.
  • Relative Value of Business: The monetary value or strategic importance the buying organization's spend brings to the supplier.

Each dimension can be assessed as ‚Äúhigh‚Äù or ‚Äúlow‚Äù, resulting in four possible categories Core, Development, Nuisance and Exploitable, as explained in the

  • Documentation: Supplier Preferencing.

We now provide an intuitive user experience for buyers to apply supplier preferencing very easily, and get an easy to understand overview for each supplier and for each strategy and plan you have created for buying from that supplier. On the right above the section an AI button ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù is shown.

Join the SAP User Research Panel. Since then many users across all areas have signed up.

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Templates in SAP Build Store: A UX-Led Transformation
entry.content:
In early 2024, we discovered something surprising.
The average user spent just 1 minute and 14 seconds in the SAP Build Store. Even more striking: nearly 60% of users left within 15 seconds.

We had invested in pre-designed, ready-to-use solutions, what we call Templates, to accelerate project creation, reduce repetitive tasks, and improve efficiency across SAP Build. But the data told us something else: the feature was practically invisible.

The challenge: our locked treasure

Why was engagement so low? Our research revealed a few key reasons:

  • Terminology like ‚ÄúStore‚Äù and ‚ÄúReady to Use‚Äù was confusing
  • The design was outdated and not aligned with SAP‚Äôs Fiori guidelines
  • Navigation was weak, leaving users without clear entry points
  • Most users only discovered the feature via a lobby shortcut. Without it, usage dropped dramatically

We had a powerful capability, but no visibility.

The original design: outdated, unclear, and often overlooked

 

Strategic context and research

This redesign was not done in isolation. It aligned with the SAP Build 2025 strategy, which emphasizes predefined processes and best practices to accelerate time to value.

We also reviewed how similar solutions in the market are positioned. A common theme was the strong emphasis on clarity and discoverability, which reinforced the importance of making SAP‚Äôs Templates more visible and actionable

 

The big idea: make Templates impossible to ignore

Our guiding principle was simple: Visibility, Clarity, Efficiency.
If users did not see it, they would not use it.

So the mission was twofold:

  1. Make Templates more discoverable, even without shortcuts
  2. Clarify their purpose so users could quickly understand and act

 

Transformation in action

We redesigned the experience with these goals in mind:

  • Consistency: A modern, structured UI aligned with SAP‚Äôs design language
  • Navigation: Clearer pathways and filters so users could find relevant templates more easily
  • Cards: A more engaging presentation with images, clearer actions, and hierarchy
  • Clarity: New status badges and improved copy to reduce confusion
  • Guidance: A new dialog to help users understand the difference between Pre-built and Sample templates
  • Terminology: We also introduced several naming changes to reduce confusion and better reflect the feature‚Äôs purpose, such as renaming ‚ÄúStore‚Äù to Templates, ‚ÄúReady to Use‚Äù to Pre-built, and ‚ÄúTemplate‚Äù to Sample. These adjustments might look small, but they made the feature‚Äôs value clearer and easier to understand.

In short, the redesign turned Templates from a hidden corner into a visible, structured, and valuable part of the experience.

The redesigned templates: clearer hierarchy, modern visuals, and consistent actions..

 New Select Template dialog: shown when creating a template that supports both options, helping users choose between Pre-built and Sample with clearer guidance.

 

Testing with users

To validate the new approach, we ran two usability studies:

  • July 2024: with 6 internal SAP colleagues who used the Store daily
  • December 2024: with 5 SAP customers from Vodafone, AIRBUS, Merck, and Twinnings

The feedback was clear:

  • Users finally understood Templates
  • Many admitted they had not known the feature even existed before
  • Excitement grew as they realized Templates could meaningfully support their workflows

One participant summed it up:

‚ÄúPositive step to move from Store to Template. The UI is much better from the old Store, it is awesome.‚Äù

 

The impact

This redesign has not yet been developed, and there is no confirmed timeline for implementation.
But the usability studies made one thing clear:

  • More visibility ‚Üí more usage
  • More clarity ‚Üí more efficiency
  • More usability ‚Üí more business value

 

Key takeaways

  • Do not wait for permission. If something is broken, fix it
  • Business impact and usability go hand in hand
  • Visibility is everything. If users do not see it, they will not use it

This journey reminded me that some of the most impactful UX work is not about adding new features, but about unlocking the hidden value that already exists.

Have you faced a similar challenge in making an important feature more visible and usable? I‚Äôd love to hear how you approached it in your product.

entry.title: Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime ‚Äî Check Your Browser Strategy Today!
entry.content:
This blog post was prompted by a recent issue in SAP customer support for SAP Fiori apps. I want to share the background, hoping it helps prevent a similar situation in your environment.


SAP Browser and Platform Support

SAP's Product Availability Matrix (PAM) provides the single source of truth for SAP software releases, including platform availability on browsers and operating systems. Regarding SAPUI5, note that SAPUI5 is not a product of its own, so please check the PAM for the product you're using SAPUI5 with. For more information, see SAP Note 1716423.

Browsers constantly evolve across devices to offer new capabilities and address newly detected security issues. Upgrades of browsers may introduce changes that are not backward compatible, affecting SAPUI5 and SAP software behavior. Browser upgrades may also require specific platform or operating system versions for all end users. Vendors do not provide (security) updates for browsers or platforms that are out of maintenance, which then are severe risk to productive environments. Keep in mind that SAP has no control over browser upgrades, their capabilities, or maintenance duration.

In other words: In Web development, especially with browsers: "Never touch a running system" is *NOT* an option.


Browsers for SAPUI5

SAPUI5 applications in productive SAP products require a minimum browser version to ensure full availability and security. This also lets SAPUI5 use current industry standards, such as ECMAScript, to deliver a modern and intuitive experience for SAP Business Suite.


Based on my own experience in the SAPUI5 team, I can confirm missing this requirement is a real-life risk. My conversations with customer support colleagues confirm this: productive SAP customers experienced outages because end users worked with browsers that were out of maintenance. One example can be seen in SAP Note 3639059 - Blank home screen in SAP Fiori Launchpad - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, which prompted this blog post. Using an outdated browser, end users saw a blank screen; developers got an error "Promise.withResolvers is not a function" in the console. The resolution for such cases is to update to the latest browser version, which in some cases may even require a costly operating system upgrade for all business users.

Therefore, I recommend monitoring the SAP Product Availability Matrix (PAM) and specifically the SAPUI5 Browser and Platform Support.
