Esse tutorial seria sobre o desenvolvimento de aplica√ß√µes UI5/FIORI ao publico B2C, ou seja usu√°rios que em sua maioria nunca teriam visto nada sobre SAP e que para eles seria como uma aplica√ß√£o Web qualquer, tamb√©m aplica√ß√µes essas que seriam disponibilizadas na internet para acesso do publico em geral. No Blog eu iria abordar a arquitetura recomendada, exemplos de c√≥digos fonte, etc., por√©m na etapa de pesquisa para apresentar alguns ‚Äúexemplos‚Äù j√° existentes no mercado, me deparei com cen√°rios muito assustadores!

Para contextualizar, ‚Äúo sistema SAP‚Äù sempre √© em sua maioria um sistema ‚Äúfechado‚Äù, onde o acesso √© feito geralmente por quem de fato precisa do mesmo (at√© por quest√£o de custo de licen√ßa). Analisando a minha experiencia, de colegas e muitos estudos, conseguia afirmar ent√£o que os profissionais que desenvolvem, desenham e/ou especificam solu√ß√µes SAP ao ‚Äúpublico geral‚Äù, em sua maioria n√£o tem uma preocupa√ß√£o com os quesitos de seguran√ßa. No mundo SAP, os desenvolvimentos geralmente ficam dentro do sistema e/ou na rede interna do cliente, ent√£o esse t√≥pico nunca foi muito explorado pelos profissionais e consultorias que desenvolvem solu√ß√µes customizadas, e esse aqui foi o principal motivador de iniciar todo o conte√∫do. Ou seja, profissionais do mundo SAP precisam se atentar e se preparar ao criar solu√ß√µes desse tipo, pois os impactos de n√£o fazer algo correto podem ser enormes (que ver√° logo mais alguns exemplos). Pois se algum desses casos ca√≠sse nas m√£os erradas, n√£o s√≥ a imagem da empresa em quest√£o que usa SAP, independente do pa√≠s que est√° localizada, seria impactada com preju√≠zos financeiros e at√© implica√ß√µes legais, mas n√≥s profissionais do mundo SAP tamb√©m seriamos impactados pela ‚Äúimagem‚Äù que seria passada que o sistema SAP √© de alguma maneira "inseguro".

Antes de entrarmos no detalhe tenho que falar algo importante, tudo que falarei daqui em diante diz respeito a aplica√ß√µes/servi√ßos customizados e n√£o standard SAP, ou seja foram solu√ß√µes desenvolvidas por algu√©m para atender o requisito daquele cliente em espec√≠fico, e n√£o algo que ‚Äúvem‚Äù no produto SAP. Solu√ß√µes SAP a n√≠vel de produto no geral s√£o muitos seguras, onde a mesma investe muito para manter o mais alto n√≠vel de seguran√ßa, utilizando todas as ferramentas e m√©todos de mercado para tal. At√© ter programas onde pode ‚Äúcontratar‚Äù profissionais de cyber seguran√ßa para tentar explorar e descobrir como deixar seus produtos mais seguros (onde eu posso ou n√£o ter participado. NDA). Recomendo os links 1 e 2 para quem deseja se aprofundar mais no tema de seguran√ßa no n√≠vel de produto SAP. Outro ponto importante, √© que demonstro como essas aplica√ß√µes customizadas podem ser facilmente encontradas na internet por ferramentas como Google Buscador. 

Na pesquisa fui encontrando muitas empresas vulner√°veis em um numero alt√≠ssimo, quase podendo afirmar que mais 30% das que encontrei, tinham algum problema. Ent√£o o que era um tutorial mudou para uma pesquisa mais aprofundada do tema, e com isso resolvi criar o movimento #SafeSAPUI5. Que basicamente iniciaria com a cria√ß√£o de material e conscientiza√ß√£o dos profissionais para termos aplica√ß√µes e servi√ßos SAP seguros que est√£o expostos na internet. Pois aqui entra um detalhe t√©cnico bem agravante, para muitos casos o requerimento do cliente (ou seja, o que ele precisa) √© ter uma aplica√ß√£o customizada porem sem ter a necessidade de nenhum tipo de autentica√ß√£o por parte do usu√°rio que vai acessar. Ou seja, ao clicar na URL ele j√° deve entrar na aplica√ß√£o customizada e poder fazer a a√ß√£o necess√°ria, cen√°rio esse que foge bem do ‚Äúpadr√£o‚Äù SAP e existem muitas e muitas aplica√ß√µes como essa espalhadas pelo mundo.  

Os materiais do #SafeSAPUI5 podem ser encontrados aqui.

Al√©m dos mesmos, como j√° estava pronto para escrever, resolvi criar um Ebook gratuito sobre o tema, juntando um pouco de historia, exemplos, dicas e casos reais. Com isso, nasceu o ebook UI5 Hacker, que pode ser encontrado gratuitamente aqui (Portugu√™s e Ingl√™s). 

Juntando tudo isso apresentei a primeira palestra do tema, ainda na Pandemia, no evento UI5 Con 2021 (em Ingl√™s) que √© a conferencia global de SAPUI5, biblioteca utilizada para realizar esses desenvolvimentos (mais detalhes na palestra ou ebook).

UI5CON 2021: #SafeSAPUI5: 

Depois da mesma, com a ajuda da pr√≥pria SAP, consegui espalhar essa conscientiza√ß√£o e tamb√©m comunicar os clientes ao redor do mundo que estavam inseguros e foram citados nos exemplos da palestra e ebook (alguns com vulnerabilidades muito graves, como c√≥pia do passaporte de todos os usu√°rios pronta para ser extra√≠da por exemplo). Importante, era poss√≠vel conseguir isso sem precisar realizar nenhum tipo de hack, apenas saber executar um servi√ßo/API que est√° exposto na internet (at√© pelo pr√≥prio navegador). 

Ent√£o em 2023, resolvi fazer um compilado do material de 2021 em Portugu√™s (com alguns novos exemplos) e apresentar no SIT SP 2023 (Servi√ßos Seguros & Aplica√ß√µes Seguras), trazendo a tona novamente o material e o tema (agora focado mais em Portugu√™s).

A palestra pode ser vista no Youtube aqui:

Com isso tive muitos feedbacks positivos de profissionais e de clientes SAP que resolveram suas vulnerabilidades e passaram a adotar as praticas em seu dia a dia, para esse e outros requisitos. Mas √© importante falar, √© poss√≠vel SIM fazer uma aplica√ß√£o WEB como essa que descrevi acima de maneira segura e protegida para o seu cliente, s√≥ seguir as boas praticas e utilizar as ferramentas corretas. Acontece que nesse "meio tempo", a ado√ß√£o do SAP BTP (oferta da SAP de servi√ßos Cloud, assim como os outros grandes players de tecnologia) cresceu exponencialmente no mundo todo. Se iniciou ent√£o um movimento de muitos clientes para levarem suas solu√ß√µes para o BTP (conhecido como o movimento ‚Äúmove to cloud‚Äù), e alguns deles com aplica√ß√µes se enquadrando nas poss√≠veis vulnerabilidades descritas. 

Mas e ent√£o, apenas levar as aplica√ß√µes ao BTP as deixam seguras? 

E com a chegada, populariza√ß√£o e massiva utiliza√ß√£o/evolu√ß√£o das Intelig√™ncias Artificiais (IAs) impactam nisso tudo?

Para responder as quest√µes acima e trazer a tona novamente o tema, resolvi criar o material da palestra apresentada no SIT Londrina 2025: ‚ÄúSeguran√ßa em Aplica√ß√µes/Servi√ßos no BTP em √©pocas de IA‚Äù. Mas como comentei antes, o evento foi somente presencial e por conta disso resolvi realizar uma ‚Äúlive‚Äù com o mesmo material e conte√∫do para disponibilizar a todos o mesmo. Colocando em uma linha do tempo ent√£o, ficaria assim:

O PDF do material apresentado no SIT Londrina 2025 pode ser encontrado aqui.

Ap√≥s a apresenta√ß√£o desse material (PDF e "Live"), demonstro que uma simples ida ao SAP BTP com aplica√ß√µes nesse modelo n√£o te deixar√° mais seguro. E com a chegada das IAs, existe hoje uma r√°pida revolu√ß√£o no segmento de Cyber Security (assim como o mundo em geral) que as empresas que utilizam solu√ß√µes SAP devem estar atentas e preparadas. 

Espero que tenha gostado do conte√∫do e lhe ajudado, e que de alguma maneira tenha agregando algo ao seu conhecimento atual. 

Obrigado e nos vemos nas pr√≥ximas aventuras do ‚ÄúHacker do Bem‚Äù.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur
entry.content:
This sixth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur. For SAP Customer Experience, look at the new AI agents and the capability to build custom agents, plus AI innovations for marketeers in SAP Emarsys, and Joule and AI order summaries in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.  SAP Concur takes travel planning to the next level with the whole new travel experience, complemented by the new Joule Booking Agent enabling users to use natural language to book a trip.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 

SAP Customer Experience

The user experience highlights I have picked are all AI-related:

  • AI Agents.
  • SAP Emarsys UX innovations.
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 UX innovations.

This news article summarizes what‚Äôs new overall for SAP Customer Experience, beyond UX-related innovations:

  • Connected for Growth: What‚Äôs New with SAP Customer Experience in Q2 2025.

AI Agents

As I explained in part 1 of this series, AI agents work in the background to give a greatly enhanced user experience. A number of powerful AI agents are available for SAP Customer Experience, via the package Joule Premium for Customer Experience. This blog post and video give a nice overview of three of them in action:

  • AI Agents in Action.
  • Video: See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service (3:11 min.)

The latest UX innovations are:

  • Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant.
  • Digital Service Agent (via Early Adopter Care program).
  • Ability to create custom agents in the CX AI Toolkit.

AI Shopping Agent for the SAP Commerce Cloud Shopping Assistant

The shopping agent helps customers when visiting an online shop: they can simply use natural language to state what they are looking for, and the shopping agent will respond with suitable suggestions. Figure 1 shows an example, where the user starts out by stating that they are looking for shoes to wear for two mile long walks while wearing a suit. Two shoes are suggested, and the user asks which one is comfortable right away, since he doesn‚Äôt want a long break in period. The agent recommends one model, and the customer then asks for a recommendation for a belt to match, which the agent promptly gives him.

Figure 1: Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant from SAP Commerce Cloud. Alt Text: three screenshots of a tall and narrow screen showing a chat, one for each of the interactions explained in the main text. Each response shows one or two images: in the first case two shoes, then one shoe and then one men‚Äôs belt.

Find out more here, and watch the video embedded there to see it in action:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Shopping Agent

Digital Service Agent

The new digital service agent helps to provide your customers with a great user experience, similar to how the shopping agent is aimed primarily at your customers. It enables customers to ask questions with natural language and provides answers based on your company‚Äôs business knowledge residing in the SAP system. Hence, it is able to resolve common inquiries and issues, giving customers a good experience. Furthermore, by freeing up you sales and service team to focus on more complex inquiries, your customers will also receive a better service and hence better experience.

The digital serice agent is currently only available for select customers via the Early Adopter Care program. Figure 2 in the next section shows how these customers can select it in the AI Agent Builder.

Find out more here:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Digital Service Agent.

Create Custom Agents with CX AI Toolkit

You can now create your own custom agents with the CX AI toolkit. Figure 2 shows the start screen for the AI Agent Builder, where you can select ‚ÄúCustom Tool‚Äù to start the wizard which takes you through the steps to create a custom agent.

Figure 2: The AI Agent Builder in the CX AI Tookit for creating custom AI agents or using SAP templates to create AI agents. Alt Text: A screenshot with ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Create AI Agents‚Äù in large text in the middle below an illustration, below in much smaller text ‚ÄúStart by selecting an Agent Template‚Äù. Below that, two rows of three cards representing Agent Templates are shown: Custom Tool, Knowledge Agent, Classification Agent, Digital Service Agent, Q/A Agent, and Shopping Assistant Agent.

Find out more here:

  • Documentation: Create a Custom AI Agent.

Further Information on AI Agents for SAP Customer Experience

For a deeper understanding of the power of these AI agents, have a look at this longer video:

  • Video: SAP CX AI Toolkit: AI Insights Agents for SAP C4C & Shopping Assistant | Product Inspiration Series (32:21 min.)

SAP Emarsys

AI-Assisted Report Builder using Natural Language

You can now easily create a report using natural language to describe what you are interested in. Figure 3 shows an example of the entry screen. At the bottom you see hints on what kind of queries you can enter.

Figure 3: AI-assisted report builder in SAP Emarsys. Alt Text: A screenshot with ‚ÄúUnlock the Power of Data with the AI-assisted Report Builder‚Äù in the middle. At the top a text entry field containing the query ‚ÄúWhat are the Sent, Delivered, Bounced, Opened, Clicked, Purchased, Unsubscribed, Complained for my Email campaigns in the past month?‚Äù, to the right an AI button ‚ÄúGenerate Report‚Äù. At the bottom of the screen two example queries are listed.

Once you have created the report, you can easily adjust it using a set of convenient filters, such as the date range as well as the list of campaigns and metrics. Watch this video to see it in action:

  • Video: AI-assisted Report Builder (46 seconds).

AI-assisted Product Finder using Natural Language (Pilot)

Pilot customers can now try out the new AI-assisted product finder, which allows users to search for product to add to marketing campaigns using natural language. Figure 4 shows an example of how to enter your search text, see more here:

  • Video: AI-assisted Product Finder (38 seconds).

Figure 4: AI-assisted product finder available to SAP Emarsys pilot customers. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a screen with a left half containing the Product Finder, with a search field containing ‚ÄúMost popular shoes in the last 6 month‚Äù, above an empty space with the text ‚ÄúWelcome to Product Finder!‚Äù in the middle. The right half shows an image of someone dancing in the sun and an image of a dress, along with some describing text.

Read more about latest SAP Emarsys innovations here:

  • SAP Emarsys Q2 2025 Product Release.
  • SAP Emarsys introduces new generative AI capabilities in June Product Release

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Joule in SAP Sales Cloud

Joule is now available in SAP Sale Cloud Verion 2, helping users get quick insights, for example about an account. As you can see in Figure 5, these insights can be charts as well as text based.

Figure 5: Joule for SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot of Joule showing Customer Account Overview, with the text ‚ÄúShow Key Metrics‚Äù entered as chat, below which a card with a vertical stacked bar chart shows credit limit usage (remaining amount and exposure amount), below that a card showing Key Metrics (Activity) and part of a donut chart for Tasks, Phone Calls, Appointments, Visits etc.

Have a deeper look here:

  • Video: Intelligent Selling with Joule in SAP Sales Cloud & SAP S/4HANA Cloud | Product Inspiration Series (16:04 min.)

Sales Order Summary

The Sales Order Summary uses generative AI to summarize key information about the sales order, as well as including information about some changes, for example how the price compares to the original price. Figure 6 shows an example, with the insights shown on the left of the screen.

Figure 6: Sales Order Summary in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a sales order, with the left third showing an overview with AI-generated insights such as ‚Äú13 days past requested date‚Äù, ‚ÄúOverall discount is EUR 808.55‚Äù. On the right, the Order Summary tab is shown, with account name, net and gross value, pricing stats, above ‚ÄúProducts in Cart (2)‚Äù showing a list of two products, followed by the top part of a list of pricing steps.

Learn more here:

  • Documentation: Sales Order Summary.

 

SAP Concur

The new Concur Travel experience makes it much easier to book travel involving multiple bookings, such as a flight plus hotel plus rental car. And if you just need to book one item, you can do that very easily now with the new Booking Agent powered by Joule.

New Concur Travel Experience

When travelling for a few days, one often needs to book more than one item. A typical combination is booking a flight, a hotel and a rental car. Up until now, you have had to book each item separately and take care that the dates and time match. Now, with the new Concur Travel experience, planning and booking is much easier: you can enter the start and end dates for your flight, and the new feature Match Flight Booking is applied to the hotel and car, so that dates and time match automatically.

Figures 7 to 11 show what this looks like: Figure 7 shows the start screen, where you select which items you want to include (flight, hotel, car, train). Figure 8 shows the flight view, where flight dates have been entered. Figure 9 shows the hotel search, with the default selection ‚ÄúBased on flight selection‚Äù, and similarly Figure 10 shows the rental car search, with pick-up and return times calculated based on the flight schedule. Figure 11 shows the finalize screen, in this case showing that the flight and hotel has been selected but the rental car is still open.

Figure 7: New Concur Travel experience start screen. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over with a large image of a magnifying glass on a globe, above the text ‚ÄúStart Planning‚Äù. Below that four check boxes in a row: Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train, at the bottom ‚ÄúContinue‚Äù and ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù buttons.

Figure 8: New Concur Travel experience screen with flight details. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a trip planning for a Trip to Las Vegas. The left third of the screen shows a list with items Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, with Flight selected. Below the list buttons ‚ÄúAdd to trip‚Äù and ‚ÄúSearch‚Äù. On the right a selector for round-trip (selected), one-way or multi-city, with fields for from / to locations and a date field for the stard and end date. To the right a button ‚ÄúTime preferences‚Äù and a drop-down for selecting ‚ÄúCabin‚Äù.

Figure 9: New Concur Travel experience screen with hotel details. Alt Text: As for Figure 8, but with Hotel selected, and on the right Hotel Search displayed, with the fields for ‚ÄúHotel, location, or name‚Äù and ‚ÄúDates‚Äù filled with the text ‚ÄúBased on flight selection‚Äù.

 Figure 10: New Concur Travel experience screen with rental car details. Alt Text: As for Figure 9, but with Rental Car selected, and on the right Rental Car Search displayed, with the fields for ‚ÄúPickup‚Äù and ‚ÄúDates‚Äù filled with the text ‚ÄúBased on flight selection‚Äù and the field ‚ÄúDrop-off‚Äù filled with ‚ÄúSame as pickup‚Äù. Pickup Time and Drop-off Time fields have 10:00 AM entered.

Figure 11: New Concur Travel experience finalize screen. Alt Text: Screenshot showing ‚ÄúTrip to Las Vegas‚Äù on the left two-thirds, with a card summarizing the flight with United Airlines from San Antonio, TX (SAT) ‚Äì Las Vegas, NV (LAS) and a card summarizing the hotel Courtyard by Marriott Las Vegas. The right third shows the Estimated Total Cost $2497.85 above a list with the cost of each item (flight, hotel, rental car), and buttons for ‚ÄúFinalize Trip‚Äù and ‚ÄúCancel Trip‚Äù, and options to book anything else (Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train).

As you can see in Figure 11, another advantage of the new experience is that you get budget transparency at the trip level. Also, you have flexibility to book parts of the travel now and other parts later.

Technically it supports deep linking, which means that you can send a trip-level link to colleagues which includes all the trip parts, making it easy to coordinate trip planning when travelling with others.

To find out more, have a look at the

  • Documentation: Trip Planning in New Concur Travel.

Booking Agent in Concur Travel

The new Booking Agent lets you use natural language to book business travel which is compliant with company policy and budget constraints as well as taking into account your personal travel preferences.

Figure 12 shows an example where the user has simply stated ‚ÄúI want to book a flight from San Francisco to London on Sept 9th and back on Sept 13th‚Äù. The answer shown takes into account the user‚Äôs frequent traveler memberships, flight availability and company policies.

Figure 12: New Concur Travel Booking Agent in Joule. Alt Text: A screenshot of Concur Travel with Joule opened on the right, the content is explained in the main text, with the possible flights listed alongside a thumbnail image representing the airline ‚ÄújetBlue‚Äù.

Watch it in action and find out more:

  • Video: Concur Travel ‚Äì Booking Agent demo (2:33 min.)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Booking Agent.

 

Continue Reading - UX Innovations in UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile

I hope you enjoyed this sixth part, covering SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur, with great new AI-powered user experiences helping users work more efficiently and effectively.

Here is the link to the final part seven, covering latest innovations in UI design and technology for web and mobile:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
entry.content:
This seventh and last post in my series gives an overview innovations in our UI tools and technologies, making it ever easier to design, build and integrate UIs, for both web and mobile applications. For designing apps, web and mobile, we have a new SAP Design System portal and UI Kits in Figma. For developers, we have added further AI assistance, as well as many individual improvements, including support for the latest international accessibility standard WCAG 2.2. Fun fact: SAPUI5 is now used on all 7 continents ‚Äì yes, Antarctica too! 

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

The above post also gives an update on building your own Joule agents, so I will not cover that here, but rather focus on web and mobile UI development.

 

Design News

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits in Figma

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

Figure 1: The SAP Design System portal start page. Alt Text: Image with header saying ‚ÄúSAP Design System‚Äù, with a ‚ÄúSee what‚Äôs new‚Äù button below it, and then four subsections in a horizontal row: SAP Fiori for Web, SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for iOS and SAP‚Äôs Digitial Design System. A ‚ÄúFeedback‚Äù button is on the bottom right.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

Figure 2: SAP‚Äôs UI Kits for Designers in Figma. Alt-Text: The image shows two rows of four cards representing UI Kits: SAP Fiori for Android, SAP Fiori for Web, Designing for Performance, SAP Fiori for iOS, SAP Fiori for watchOS, SAP Fiori for Wear OS, SAP S/4HANA for Web, and Accessibility Design Tools. On the very left of the image information about SAP is listed, with links to resources such as www.sap.com/design-system.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite

Consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises. We have identified areas directly relevant to users and plan to introduce a number of design updates in SAP Fiori for web across our suite of products to further increase consistency.

The areas we have redesigned and which we plan to provide across our suite of products this year and next year are:

  • Shell bar (at the top of the user‚Äôs screen)
  • Navigation menu: side navigation (see Figure 3 below).
  • User menu
  • Notifications
  • Search in the shell bar

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition already supports the first four of these, you can have a look at them in part 2 of this series, in the section SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad.

As outlined in Part 1, SAP Build Work Zone standard edition also supports side navigation.

Find out more about these design updates here:

  • Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web).

We also provide designers with a refreshed new set of illustrations, to be used for illustrated messages. Figure 3 shows some examples.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

News for Creating Web UIs

Extensibility made easy with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is made much easier since we introduced the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard. The latest update introduces the ability to create an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension.

Figure 4: Creating an SAPUI5 adaptation project as a User Interface Extension. Alt Text: Screenshot showing step 1 ‚ÄúExtension‚Äù task where users can select from a row of four cards ‚ÄúCustom Field‚Äù, ‚ÄúCustom Logic‚Äù, ‚ÄúCustom Process‚Äù and ‚ÄúUser Interface Extension‚Äù. The latter has a subtext ‚ÄúAdapt the current application or extend it visually with a new application‚Äù. The latter two cards have a link ‚ÄúManage SAP Build Projects‚Äù at the bottom. The bottom right shows two buttons ‚ÄúNext‚Äù and ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù.

Learn more here:

  • SAP Build Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Simplify SAPUI5 Code Extensions with the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard

AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter

UI5 linter is the tool of choice to check your UI5 project for using best practices and replacement of deprecated SAPUI5 APIs. With UI5 linter v1.12.0, we are happy to announce the initial version of an autofix feature: Use the "--fix" argument to let UI5 linter apply fixes to your code automatically. Read more about it here:

  • Migrate your code with UI5 linter ‚Äì Autofix has landed.

Legacy-free version of SAPUI5 available via cloud access

Once you have removed code which uses deprecated SAPUI5 APIs, you can try out the legacy-free version of SAP UI5 in the cloud, which has all deprecated code removed. Discover the benefits and how to try it out in this blog post:

  • Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don‚Äôt accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging ‚Äì so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2

SAP Fiori tools ‚Äì open source, faster app creation, more AI

One of the most powerful recent innovations is the AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools, which allows you to create a fully functional app with database tables, CDS-Views, OData service and a Fiori element list report UI based on a sketch of what you want. I introduced this in my Q1 update post from March. This can now be started from Joule in SAP Build Code. Also, it has been further enhanced, and is also available as open source, so that our developer community can make contributions themselves. Find out more here:

  • From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps
  • SAP Fiori Application Generator Available in Open Source

For those of you developing in ABAP, we have introduced the new quick SAP Fiori application generator to create and deploy simple SAP Fiori applications from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse. Have a closer look:

  • Quickly Generate and Deploy SAP Fiori Apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

To get an overview of these plus some additional enhancements, have a look at:

  • SAP Fiori tools 2506 update ‚Äì Open source, faster app creation, adaptation boost, AI enhancements.

Enhancements for SAP Fiori Elements with OData V4

We are continuously enhancing SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements. I have picked two enhancements to highlight here for developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4, which are covered in the following subsections:

  • Support for inline edit for object pages.
  • Support for the analytical table on the object page.

Support for inline edit for object pages

You can now develop object pages where users can directly edit fields within facets, without having to first press the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button and go into edit mode. Figure 5 shows an example from a test application.

Figure 5: Inline editing of fields in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of part of an object page ‚ÄúTravel‚Äù, which is overall in display mode, but the field ‚ÄúStarting Date‚Äù has been selected and is editable, with a new entry made, and ‚ÄúSave‚Äù and ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù icons next to the field.

Support for the analytical table on the object page

For applications where users need to be able to analyze the data in a table, for example grouping data and aggregating data, developers should use the analytical table rather than the responsive table.

These tables are often used for the ‚Äúlist‚Äù part of an SAP Fiori elements list report, which consists of a list and an object page for the details. Now, developers using SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements on OData V4 can include an analytical table into one of the facets of an object page. Figure 6 shows an example.

Figure 6: Analytical table in an object page with SAP Fiori elements for OData V4. Alt Text: A screenshot of an object page with a facet ‚ÄúJournal Entries (4)‚Äù which contains an analytical table, where the entries are grouped by ‚ÄúCase Journal Entry‚Äù. One of the groups is expanded, showing two lines. Below them the sum of the debit column is shown for the expanded group, and below that for the entire table.

Further Updates for SAPUI5

As I described in part 1 of this series, we have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

Key users can create consistent text changes with SAPUI5 flexibility. I described this in the context of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in part 2 of this series (section Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column). They can also easily change the labels used, to fit terms established within the company. Read more about this here:

  • How Key Users Create Consistent Text Changes with SAPUI5 Flexibility.

SAPUI5 has reached a new milestone: it is now used on all 7 continents. Yes, we have reached Antarctica!

  • SAPUI5 adoption becoming more universal.

In case you have not updated your system for a while, then be aware that we are removing SAP Fiori themes Belize and Blue Crystal. Also, make sure that you are using the latest browser versions, which may mean ensuring that your users laptops and desktops are using newer operating system versions:

  • Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal
  • Prevent an SAP Fiori / SAPUI5 Downtime ‚Äî Check Your Browser Strategy Today!

To get a complete overview of all the enhancements in SAPUI5 including SAP Fiori elements, look at the UI5 demo kit. You‚Äôll find some of the enhancements mentioned above listed under version 1.136.

  • What‚Äôs New in SAP UI5.

 

News for Mobile Designers and Developers

The main news for mobile designers are the new SAP Design System portal, which covers Android and iOS as well as the latest releases of the mobile Figma design kits for Android, iOS, WatchOs and WearOS.

Figure 7: The Android and iOS pages in the new SAP Design System portal. Alt Text: Both screenshots look the same, except for Android vs iOS text. The top has a ‚ÄúGet Started‚Äù section, with a row of cards to navigate to UI Elements, UI Kit, Development Documentation. Below that a ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù section, with information about the latest release ‚ÄúSAP Fiori for Android version 25.8‚Äù and ‚Äú‚Ä¶for iOS‚Ä¶‚Äù.

The best place to stay up-to-date with these latest enhancements is the respective What‚Äôs New section in the SAP Design System portal:

Figure 8 shows two of the many new enhancements: the new illustrations mentioned earlier in the section on web UIs are also available for mobile, both for iOS and Android. The other example shown there is the updated date picker for Android, which now allows users to select date ranges.

Figure 8: On the left, an example of the new illustrated messages for mobile. On the right, date ranges can now be selected in the date picker for Android. Alt Text: The illustrated message is used in a pop-over. The illustration shows a sheet of paper with a tickmark, below that the text ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all caught up‚Ä¶‚Äù and two buttons ‚ÄúAdd Task‚Äù and ‚ÄúRemind Me Later‚Äù. On the right two date screens are shown for the month of April: the left one has the 8th marked, the right one has the range from 8th to 16th marked.

Developers get new features with the latest releases of the mobile SDKs, as well as the the Mobile Development Kit (MDK) which is integrated into SAP Build Code. Here are links to find out more about them:

Final words

As you can see from all seven posts in the series, we continue to progress rapidly with the user experience of our product portfolio, especially with regards to AI-assistance.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

entry.title: Rise With the Phoenix: Your SAPUI5 Coding Journey Using the Demo Kit
entry.content:

entry.title: SAP Fiori Tools Update ‚Äì First Release of the SAP Fiori MCP Server for Agentic AI Workflows
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce the release of the SAP Fiori MCP server, a new capability that lets AI coding assistants directly create and edit SAP Fiori applications. This marks the next milestone in our AI journey, following the Project Accelerator introduced earlier this year.

What is MCP ‚Äî and why it matters?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models. MCP is already supported by clients such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, and VS Code allowing AI-powered workflows to interact seamlessly with developer tools.

Introducing the SAP Fiori MCP server

The SAP Fiori MCP server (@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server) is an open-source node.js module delivered as part of the open-ux-tools repository. It enables developers using AI coding assistants to generate and adapt SAP Fiori elements applications with precision and context awareness.

It is not the only MCP server published by SAP. The CAP MCP server (@cap-js/mcp-server) provides tools to create and modify CAP node.js projects, and the UI5 MCP server (@ui5/mcp-server) allows AI assistants to write SAPUI5 code. Together, these servers provide complementary entry points into different areas of SAP application development, so that AI assistants can seamlessly data models, SAP Fiori applications, and SAPUI5 code.

For more information also have a look at the related blog posts:

  • Boost your CAP Development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP
  • Give Your AI Agent Some Tools: Introducing the UI5 MCP Server

With the MCP servers in place, you can already try out scenarios such as:

  • ‚ÄúPlease add an SAP Fiori elements list report app to my CAP project.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúGenerate a new CAP project and SAP Fiori app based on my_sketch.png.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúAdd Flexible Column Layout to the app.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúEnable initial load for the SAP Fiori app.‚Äù

‚ö†Ô∏è Note: The SAP Fiori MCP server is currently released in experimental state and subject to rapid change and enhancements.

AI assistants can discover and act on SAP Fiori projects

The first release comes with a set of capabilities designed to let AI assistants both discover and act on SAP Fiori projects. The SAP Fiori MCP server provides tools to generate SAP Fiori elements applications for CAP node.js projects, finds SAP Fiori applications in the workspace, and allows to edit applications and pages inside applications.

To ensure that the AI produces correct results, we propose rules that guide the LLM‚Äôs behavior (see rules). These rules cover important aspects such as using proper SAP Fiori elements application patterns, ensuring data models are valid with UUID primary keys, generating sample data consistently, and preferring code-based modifications over screen personalization.

You can configure the server to be directly called with npx or install it globally via npm (see usage). In both cases, it integrates easily into an MCP-enabled client such as Cline.

Example how the SAP Fiori MCP server is used in Cline.

Developers can build apps more quickly using MCP servers

By connecting directly into SAP Fiori projects through MCP, developers gain a much more cost-effective way to experiment with AI support. They can let LLMs execute complex tasks in context‚Äîwhile the built-in functions and rules ensure adherence to SAP Fiori best practices. This reduces the risk of hallucinations, accelerates prototyping, and makes it easier to iterate quickly on new ideas. Since the SAP Fiori MCP server is with other MCP servers like UI5 and CAP, developers can benefit from a consistent AI-driven experience across different parts of the development process.

This is the first step on the MCP journey

The current release is just the first step. We are already working on extending the server with a document search feature that will make guidance from SAP documentation, tutorials, and examples directly available to the LLM. This means that the AI assistant won‚Äôt just follow rules embedded in the server but can also draw from the wealth of published learning content.

In addition, the generator functionality, which in the first release is limited to CAP node.js projects, will be expanded to support any suitable OData source. This will significantly broaden the scenarios in which the SAP Fiori MCP server can be applied, giving developers much more flexibility in how they use AI to create and adapt applications.

Try the SAP Fiori MCP server at SAP TechEd 2025

You can experience the SAP Fiori MCP server live at SAP TechEd Berlin. In session CA261 ‚Äì Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5, we‚Äôll guide you through using AI and MCP to generate applications, adapt them, and extend them with SAPUI5. It‚Äôs a hands-on workshop designed to show how these new capabilities come together in practice.

Closing

This release marks the start of a new era in SAP Fiori development, where AI assistants can not only suggest but also execute tasks reliably. With upcoming enhancements like doc search and broader generator support, we‚Äôre laying the groundwork for smarter, faster, and more flexible AI-driven development. As an open-source project we also welcome your contributions. We encourage you to report any issues you encounter. Your feedback is invaluable to us.

We can‚Äôt wait to see how you experiment with it‚Äîand we look forward to meeting you at TechEd!

entry.title: An SAP UI5 application to Export Data to Excel sheet (Spreadsheet) from SAP UI5 table (sap.ui.table)
entry.content:
Hi SAP UI5 family,

    In this article, we are going to understand how to implement  export functionality the sap.ui.table table data to the excel(Spreadsheet) using  sap.ui.export.Spreadsheet library. In this application, we are going to create an SAP UI5 free style application which has sample employee JSON data that has been binded to the UI table and a toggle button has been added to trigger the export or downloading the excel data.
   
This is step by step guide to create a fiori application with SAP UI5 UI table and Export Button
Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the  Fiori Generator Freestyle - Basic template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

Application Folder Structure: 

Step 2 : Create a Dynamic Page , add UI Table Details and Add the sample JSON Data in controller 

  In TableView.view.xml, Add this code and add the Sample JSON data model object in the onInit() in TableView.Controller.js .

TableView.view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="exporttoexcelex1.controller.TableView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns:m="sap.m"
    xmlns="sap.ui.table"
    xmlns:f="sap.f"
>
    <f:DynamicPage>
        <f:title>
            <f:DynamicPageTitle >
            <f:heading >
              <m:Title level="H2" text="SAP UI5 - Example : UI Table To Excel Export" />
            </f:heading>

            </f:DynamicPageTitle>
        </f:title>
        <f:content>
            <Table
                id="exportTable"
                rows="{/modelData}"
                enableColumnFreeze="true"
                selectionMode="Single"
            >
                <extension>
                    <m:OverflowToolbar>
                        <m:Title text="{i18n>title}" />
                        <m:ToolbarSpacer />
                        <m:ToggleButton id="export_btn" text="{i18n>export_btn}" icon="sap-icon://excel-attachment" press="onExcelExport"/>

                    </m:OverflowToolbar>
                </extension>
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>name}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text  text="{Name}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                     <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>dept}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{Department}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                     <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>buiAddress}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{BuiAddress}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <m:Label text="{i18n>phone}" />
                        <template>
                            <m:Text text="{Phone}" />
                        </template>
                    </Column>
                </columns>
            </Table>
        </f:content>
    </f:DynamicPage>
</mvc:View>

TableView.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet"
], (Controller, JSONModel, MessageToast, Spreadsheet) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("exporttoexcelex1.controller.TableView", {
        onInit() {
            var oView = this.getOwnerComponent();
            var oDataModel = new JSONModel();
            var oData = {
                modelData: [
                    {
                        "Name": "Raghu",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+919234521532",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Mani",
                        "Department": "Technology",
                        "BuiAddress": "Bangalore",
                        "Phone": "+919234523423",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Krishna Priya",
                        "Department": "Technology",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+919434345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Ester",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Chennai",
                        "Phone": "+91945345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    },
                    {
                        "Name": "Niraj",
                        "Department": "Finance",
                        "BuiAddress": "Hyderabad",
                        "Phone": "+91945345226",
                        "Editable": false
                    }
                ]
            }


            oDataModel.setData(oData);
            oView.setModel(oDataModel);
        },
      
    });
});

Step 3 : Implement the press event trigger of the Export To excel Button
   Add this logic in controller.js . "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library should be used for excel export.
TableView.controller.js

onExcelExport: async function (oEvent) {
            //  "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library that has been used here
            var oTable = this.byId("exportTable");
            // get Rows of the Table
            var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("rows");
            // get Columns of the Table and get the Header labels and Property values 
            var aCols = oTable.getColumns().map(function (oColumn) {
                var sProperty = oColumn.getSortProperty();
                if (!sProperty) {
                    var oTemplate = oColumn.getTemplate();
                    sProperty = oTemplate && oTemplate.getBindingPath("text");
                }
                return {
                    label: oColumn.getLabel().getText(),
                    property: sProperty,
                    type: "String"
                };
            });
            var iLength = oBinding.getLength();
            // getting Data of the Table
            // use getContexts() for odata V2
            // use requestContexts() for odata v4
            var aContexts = await oBinding.getContexts(0, iLength);
            var aData = aContexts.map(function (oContext) {
                return oContext.getObject();
            });
            // settings for the Spreadsheet
            var oSettings = {
                workbook: {
                    columns: aCols,
                },
                dataSource: aData,
                fileName: "Exported Data.xlsx",
                worker: false
            };
            // getting new Spreadsheet object and binding the settings
            var oSpreadsheet = new Spreadsheet(oSettings);
            oSpreadsheet.build().then(function () {
                MessageToast.show("Exported excel data successfully ...");
            }).finally(function () {
                oSpreadsheet.destroy();
            })
        },

Application Screen:

ExportData.xlsx

By following these steps, The SAP UI table can be exported to spreadsheet or Excel sheet

entry.title: SAP UI5 Illustrations: Enhancing UX with Purposeful Visuals
entry.content:
What Are SAP UI5 Illustrations?

SAP UI5 illustrations are visual elements that complement written messages in the user interface. They‚Äôre not just decorative‚Äîthey‚Äôre purposeful, designed to:

  • Simplify complex concepts
  • Create emotional connection
  • Guide users through unfamiliar workflows
  • Add personality to otherwise sterile enterprise screens

These illustrations are typically paired with messages in empty states, onboarding flows, error pages, or help dialogs. Think of them as visual metaphors that make abstract ideas more relatable.

Why Are They Necessary?

Here‚Äôs why illustrations are more than just eye candy in SAP UI5:

1. Improved Comprehension

Visuals help users grasp concepts faster than text alone. For example, an illustration of a magnifying glass next to a ‚ÄúNo results found‚Äù message instantly conveys the idea of search failure.

2. Emotional Engagement

Enterprise apps can feel impersonal. Illustrations add warmth and friendliness, making users feel more comfortable and confident‚Äîeven when something goes wrong.

3. Consistency Across SAP Fiori Design

SAP UI5 illustrations follow the SAP Fiori Guidelines ensuring a consistent look and feel across apps. This consistency builds trust and reduces cognitive load.

4. Accessibility and Inclusivity

Illustrations can support users with different language proficiencies or cognitive styles. When paired with clear text, they make the interface more inclusive.

5. Guided User Journeys

In onboarding or help flows, illustrations act as visual signposts. They guide users step-by-step, reducing friction and improving adoption.

Common Misuses to Avoid

SAP‚Äôs guidelines emphasize that illustrations should never:

  • Be used purely for decoration
  • Obstruct the user‚Äôs path
  • Replace essential information

They should always support the message, not distract from it.

Ô∏èHow to Use Them in SAP UI5

SAP UI5 provides a set of predefined illustrations via the sap.f library. Developers can easily integrate them using controls like IllustratedMessage, which combines an image, title, and description in a clean layout.

Example usage:

<sap.f.IllustratedMessage
    illustrationType="sapIllus-NoData"
    title="No Data Available"
    description="Try adjusting your filters or check back later." />

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP Incentive Management for Real-time Incentive calculation
entry.content:
Integrating SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management creates a powerful solution for real-time incentive calculation and sales performance optimization. Here's a breakdown of how this integration works and the benefits it offers:

Integration Overview

The mashup between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management enables sales teams to:

  • View real-time incentive data directly within the Sales Cloud interface.
  • Access a unified dashboard showing opportunities, leads, commissions, and payouts.
  • Receive instant updates as deals progress, with incentive data refreshed in real time.
  • Gain actionable insights into how performance affects earnings and what actions can maximize incentives.

Key Benefits

  1. Real-Time Insights & Motivation

    • Sales reps can see their commissions and performance metrics instantly.
    • Features like commission estimates, leaderboards, and performance dashboards help boost motivation.

  2. Streamlined Dispute Resolution

    • One-click traceability allows quick resolution of compensation inquiries.
    • Reduces administrative overhead and keeps reps focused on selling.

  3. Optimized Incentive Plans

    • Use AI-driven recommendations to refine compensation strategies.
    • Identify opportunities for bonuses or accelerators to maximize ROI.

  4. Flexible Plan Design

    • Easily model and test complex incentive plans using drag-and-drop tools.
    • Roll out new promotions without heavy IT involvement

Implementation Highlights

  • Once integrated, users can navigate to Sales History ‚Üí Opportunities in SAP Sales Cloud V2.
  • A new dashboard section appears showing incentives and payments.
  • The mashup is enabled via standard configuration steps provided by SAP.

Integration Flow Description

  1. SAP Sales Cloud V2

    • Opportunity is created and assigned to a Opportunity Owner (Sales Employee).
    • Opportunity data includes total revenue,opporuntiy date, product, and stage.

  2. Employee Sync

    • The Employee in Sales Cloud is synced with SuccessFactors via master data integration.
    • Employee is linked to a Position in Incentive Manager.

  3. SuccessFactors Incentive Management

    • The Position is mapped to an Incentive Plan.
    • Incentive Plan defines rules, rule elements including quotas, accelerators, and payout logic.

  4. Real-Time Calculation

    • As the Opportunity progresses, incentive calculations are triggered.
    • Sales reps can view estimated commissions, performance dashboards, and leaderboards directly in Sales Cloud.

  5. Feedback Loop

    • Incentive results are sent back to Sales Cloud for visibility.
    • Managers can adjust plans or resolve disputes using traceable data.
